titleStmt.title: a machine-readable version of Marston, John, 1575?-1634 : : Antonio and Mellida, part i (1602)

publicationStmt.publisher: John Marston, 1575?-1634 (1576-1634) The History of Antonio and Mellida. The first part. As it hath beene sundry times acted, by the children of Paules. Written by I. M. London Printed for Mathewe Lownes, and Thomas Fisher [etc.] 1602

sourceDesc.p: LION version of 1602 quarto, STC17473, checked against images of this version from EEBO

Play details
Antonio and Mellida, part i. Genre: Tragi-comedy. Date first published: 1602. Date first performed: 1599-1600.

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Piero Alberto Galeatzo Balurdo Forobosco Feliche Antonio Matzagente Flauia Rossaline Mellidia Dildo Catzo Castilio Andrugio Lucio Page Painter Prologue etc.

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage: The Play called Antonio and Mellida. Induction.
Enter Galeatzo, Piero, Alberto, Antonio, Forobosco, Balurdo, Matzagente, & Feliche, with parts in their hands: hauing cloakes cast ouer their apparell.

sp.l: Come sirs, come: the music will sound straight for entrance. Are ye ready, are ye perfect?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Faith, we can say our parts: but we are ignorant in what mold we must cast our Actors.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Whom do you personate?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Piero, Duke of Venice.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: O, ho: then thus frame your exterior shape,
To haughty form of elate majesty;
As if you held the palsy shaking head
Of reeling chance, under your fortunes belt,
In strictest vassalage: grow big in thought,
As swollen with glory of successful arms.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: If that be all, fear not, I will suit it right.
Who cannot be proud, stroke up the hair, and strut!

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Truth: such rank custom is grown popular;
And now the vulgar fashion strides as wide,
And stalks as proud, upon the weakest stilts
Of the slightest fortunes, as if Hercules,
Or burly Atlas shouldered up their state.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Good: but whom act you?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: The necessity of the play forceth me to act two parts; Andrugio, the distressed Duke of Genoa, and Alberta, a Venetian gentleman, enamoured on the Lady Rossaline: whose fortunes being too weak to sustain the port of her, he proved always disastrous in love : his worth being much underpoised by the uneven scale, that currants all things by the outward stamp of opinion.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Well, and what dost thou play?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: The part of all the world.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: The part of all the world? What is that?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: The fool. I in good deed law now, I play Balurdo, a wealthy mountebanking Burgomasco's heir of Venice.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Ha, ha: one, whose foppish nature might seem great, only for wise men's recreation; and, like a Juiceless bark, to preserve the sap of more strenuous spirits. A servile hound, that loves the sent of forerunning fashion, like an empty hollow vault, still giving an echo to wit: greedily champing what any other well valued judgment had before hand showed.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha: tolerably good, good faith sweet wag.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Vmh, why tolerably good, good faith sweet wag? Go,go; you flatter me.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Right, I but dispose my speech to the habit of my part.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Why, what plays he?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: The wolf, that eats into the breast of Princes; that breeds the Lethargy and falling sickness in honour; makes Justice look asquint, and blinks the eye of merited reward from viewing desertful virtue.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: What is all this Periphrasis? ha?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: The substance of a supple-chapped flatterer.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: O, doth he play Forobosco the Parasite? Good i'faith. Sirrah, you must seem now as glib and straight in outward semblance, as a Ladies busk; though inwardly, as cross as a pair of Tailors legs:having a tongue as nimble as his needle, with servile patches of glavering flattery, to stitch up the bracks of unworthily honoured.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: I warrant you, I warrant you, you shall see me prove the very Periwig to cover the bald pate of brainless gentility. Ho, I will so tickle the sense of bella gratiosa madonna, with the titillation of Hyperbolical praise, that I will strike it in the nick, in the very nick, chuck.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Thou promisest more, than I hope any Spectator gives faith of performance: but why look you so dusky? ha?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I was never worse fitted since the nativity of my Actorship: I shalt be hist at, on my life now.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Why, what must you play?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith, I know not what: an Hermaphrodite; two parts in one: my true person being Antonio, son to the Duke of Genoa; though for the love of Mellida, Peros daughter, I take this fained presence of an Amazon, calling myself Florizell, and I know not what. I a voice to play a lady! I shall never do it.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: O, an Amazon should have such a voice, virago like. Not play two parts in one? away, away: it is common fashion. Nay if you cannot bear two subtle frots under one hood, Idiot go by, go by; off this worlds stage. O times impurity!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Aye , but when use hath taught me action, to hit the right point of a Ladies part, I shall grow ignorant when I must turn young Prince again, how but to truss my hose.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Tush never put them off: for women wear the breaches still.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: By the bright honour of a Millanoise, and the resplendent fulgor of this steel, I will defend the feminine to death; and ding his spirit to the verge of hell, that dares divulge a Ladies prejudice.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Rampum scrampum, mount tufty Tamburlaine. What rattling thunder clap breaks from his lips?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: O, it is native to his part. For, acting a modern Bragadoch under the person of Matzagente, the Duke of Millaines son, it may seem to suite with good fashion of coherence.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: But methinks he speaks with a spruce Attic accent of adulterate Spanish.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: So it is resolved. For, Millane being half Spanish, half high Dutch, and half Italians, the blood of chiefest houses, is corrupt and mongrelled: so that you shall see a fellow vainglorious, for a Spaniard; gluttonous, for a Dutchman; proud, for an Italian; and a fantastic Idiot, for all. Such a one conceit this Matzagente.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: But I have a part allotted me, which I have neither able apprehension to conceit, nor what I conceit gracious ability to utter.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Whoop, in the old cut? good show us a draught of thy spirit.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: It is steady, and must seem so impregnably fortressed with his own content, that no envious thought could ever invade his spirit:never surveying any man so unmeasuredly happy, whom I thought not justly hateful for some true impoverishment: never beholding any favour of Madam Felicity gracing another, which his well bounded content persuaded not to hang in the front of his own fortune: and therefore as far from envying any man, as he valued all men infinitely distant from accomplished beatitude. These native adjuncts appropriate to me the name of Feliche. But last, good thy humour.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is to be described by signs and tokens. For unless I were possessed with a legion of spirits, it is impossible to be made perspicuous by any utterance: For sometimes he must take austere state, as for the person of Galeatzo, the son of the duke of Florence, and possess his exterior presence with a formal majesty: keep popularity in distance, and on the sudden fling his honour so prodigally into a common Arm, that he may seem to give up his indiscretion to the mercy of vulgar censure: Now as solemn as a travailer, and as grave as a Puritans ruff: with the same breath as slight and scattered in his fashion as as as a a anything. Now, as sweet and neat as a Barbers casting-bottle; straight as slovenly as the yeasty breast of an Ale-knight: now, lamenting: then chafing: straight laughing: then

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith I know not what: it had been a right part for Proteus or Gew: ho, blind Gew would have done it rarely, rarely.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: I fear it is not possible to limb so many persons in so small a tablet as the compass of our plays afford.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Right: therefore I have heard that those persons, as he and you Feliche, that are but slightly drawn in this Comedy, should receive more exact accomplishment in a second Part: which, if this obtain gracious acceptance, means to try his fortune.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Peace, here comes the Prologue, clear the Stage.
The wreath of pleasure, and delicious sweets,
Begirt the gentle front of this fair troop:
Select, and most respected Auditors,
For wits sake do not dream of miracles.
Alas, we shall but falter, if you lay
The least sad weight of an unused hope,
Upon our weakness: only we give up
The worthless present of slight idleness,
To your authentic censure; O that our Muse
Had those abstruse and sinewy faculties,
That with a strain of fresh invention
She might press out the rarity of Art;
The purest elixed juice of rich conceit,
In your attentive ears; that with the lip
Of gracious elocution, we might drink
A sound carouse unto your health of wit.
But O, the heathy dryness of her brain,
Foil to your fertile spirits, is ashamed
To breath her blushing numbers to such ears:
Yet (most ingenious) deign to vail our wants;
With sleek acceptance, polish these rude Scenes:
And if our slightness your large hope beguiles,
Check not with bended brow, but dimpled smiles.

body.stage: The Cornets sound a battle within.
Enter Antonio, disguised like an Amazon.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Heart wilt not break! and thou abhorred life
Wilt thou still breath in my enraged blood?
Veins, sinews, arteries, why crack ye not?
Burst and divulsed, with anguish of my grief.
Can man by no means creep out of himself ,
And leave the slough of viperous grief behind?
Antonio, hast thou seen a fight at sea,
As horrid as the hideous day of doom;
Betwixt thy father, duke of Genoa,
And proud Piero, the Venetian Prince?
In which the sea hath swollen with Genoas blood,
And made spring tides with the warm reeking gore,
That gushed from out our Galleys scupper holes;
In which, thy father, poor Andrugio,
Lies sunk, or leapt into the arms of chance,
Choked with the labouring Oceans brackish foam;
Who even, despite Pieros cankered hate,
Would with an armed hand have seized thy love,
And linked thee to the beauteous Mellida.
Have I outlived the death of all these hopes?
Have I felt anguish poured into my heart,
Burning like Balsamum in tender wounds;
And yet dost live could not the fretting sea
Have rolled me up in wrinkles of his brow?
Is death grown coy? or grim confusion nice?
That it will not accompany a wretch,
But I must needs be cast on Venice shore?
And try new fortunes with this strange disguise?
To purchase my adored Mellida.
sp.stage: The Cornets sound a flourish: cease.
sp.l: Hark how Piero's triumphs beat the air,
O rugged mischief how thou gratest my heart!
Take spirit, blood, disguise, be confident:
Make a firm stand, here rests the hope of all,
Lower than hell, there is no depth to fall.

body.stage: The Cornets sound a Synnet: Enter Feliche and Alberto, Castilio and Forobosco, a Page carying a shield: Piero in Armour: Catzo and Dildo and Balurdo: All these (sauing Piero) armed with Petronels: Beeing entred, they make a stand in diuided foyles.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Victorious Fortune, with triumphant hand,
Hurleth my glory about this ball of earth,
Whilst the Venetian Duke is heaved up
On wings of fair success, to overlook
The low cast ruins of his enemies,
To see myself adored, and Genoa quake,
My fate is firmer than mischance can shake.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Stand, the ground trembleth.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Ha? an earthquake?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: O , I smell a sound.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Piero stay, for I descry a fume,
Creeping from out the bosom of the deep,
The breath of darkness, fatal when it is whist
In greatness stomach: this same smoke, called pride,
Take heed she will lift thee to improvidence,
And break thy neck from steep security,
She will make thee grudge to let Iehoua share
In thy successful battles: O, she is ominous,
Enticeth princes to devour heaven,
Swallow omnipotence, out stare dread fate,
Subdue Eternity in giant thought,
Heaves up their hurt with swelling, puffed conceit,
Till their souls burst with venomed Arrogance:
Beware Piero, Rome itself hath tried,
Confusions train blows up this Babel pride.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Pish, Dimitto superos, summa votorum attigi
Alberto, hast thou yielded up our fixed decree
Unto the Genoan Ambassador?
Are they content if that their duke return,
To send his, and his son Antonios head,
As pledges steeped in blood, to gain their peace?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: With most obsequious, sleek-browed incertain,
They all embrace it as most gracious.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Are Proclamations sent through Italy,
That whosoever brings Andrugios head,
Or young Anthonios shall be guerdoned
With twenty thousand double Pistolets,
And be indeened to Pieros love?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: They are sent every way: sound policy.
Sweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Confusion to these limber Sycophants.
No sooner mischief is borne in regency,
But flattery christens it with policy.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Why then: O me Celitum excelsissimum!
The intestine malice, and inveterate hate
I always bore to that Andrugio,
Glories in triumph over his misery:
Nor shall that carpet boy Antonio
Match with my daughter, sweet cheeked Mellida.
No, the public power makes my faction strong.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: I will, when public power strengtheneth private wrong.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: It is horse like, not for man, to know his force.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: It is god like, for a man to feel remorse.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Pish, I prosecute my families revenge,
Which I will. pursue with such a burning chase
Till I have dried up all Andrugios blood;
Weak rage, that with slight pity is withstood.
What means that fresh triumphal flourish sound?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: The prince of Millane, and young Florence heir
Approach to gratulate your victory.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: We will girt them with an ample waste of love;
Conduct them to our presence royally.
Let volleys of the great Artillery
From of our galleys banks play prodigal,
And sound loud welcome from their bellowing mouths.

body.stage: The Cornets sound a Cynet. Enter aboue, Mellida, Rossaline and Flauia: Enter belowe, Galeatzo with attendants: Piero meeteth him, embraceth; at which the Cornets sound a florish: Piero and Galeatzo exeunt: the rest stand still.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: What prince was that passed through my fathers guard?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: It was the young Florentine.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Troth, one that will besiege thy maidenhead,
Enter the walls i'faith (sweet Mellida)
If that thy flankers be not Canon proof.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: O Mary Ambree, good, thy judgment wench;
Thy bright elections clear, what will he prove?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Hath a short finger and a naked chin;
A skipping eye, dare lay my judgment (faith)
His love is glibbery;there is no hold of it, wench:
Give me a husband whose aspect is firm,
A full cheeked gallant, with a bouncing thigh:
O , he is the Paradizo dell madonne contento.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Even such a one was my Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: By my nine and thirtieth servant (sweet)
Thou art in love, but stand on tiptoed fair,
Here comes Saint Tristram Tirlery whiff i'faith.

body.stage: Enter Matzagente, Piero meetes him, embraceth; at which the Cornets sound a florish: they two stand, vsing seeming complements, whilst the Sceane passeth aboue.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Saint Mark, Saint Mark, what kind of thing appears?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: For fancies passion, spit upon him; fie:
His face is varnished: in the name of love,
What country bred that creature?

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: What is he Flauia?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: The heir of Millane, Seignior Matzagent.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Matzagent? now by my pleasures hope,
He is made like a tilting staff; and looks
For all the world like an over roasted pig:
A great Tobacco taker too,that is flat.
For his eyes look as if they had been hung
In the smoke of his nose.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: What husband, will he prove sweet Rossaline?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Avoid him: for he hath a dwindled leg,
A lowe forehead, and a thin coal-black beard,
And will be jealous too, believe it sweet:
For his chin sweats, and hath a gander neck,
A thin lip, and a little monkish eye:
Precious, what a slender waste he hath!
He looks like a May-pole, or a notched stick:
He will snap in two at every little strain.
Give me a husband that will fill mine arms,
Of steady judgment, quick and nimble sense:
Fools relish not a Ladies excellence.

body.stage: Exeunt all on the lower Stage: at which the Cornets sound a florish, and a peale of shot is giuen.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: The triumph is ended, but look Rossaline,
What gloomy soul in strange accoutrements
Walks on the pavement.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Good sweet let us to her, prithee Mellida.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: How covetous thou art of novelties!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Pish, it is our nature to desire things
That are thought strangers to the common cut.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: I am exceeding willing, but ~~

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: But what? prithee go down, let us see her face:
God send that neither wit nor beauty wants
Those tempting sweets, affections Adamants.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Come down, she comes like: O, no Simile
Is precious, choice, or elegant enough
To illustrate her descent: leap heart, she comes,
She comes: smile heaven, and softest Southern wind
Kiss her cheek gently with perfumed breath.
She comes: Creations purity, admired,
Adored, amazing rarity, she comes.
O now Antonio press thy spirit forth
In following passion, knit thy senses close,
Heap up thy powers, double all thy man:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She comes. O how her eyes dart wonder on my heart!
Mount blood, soul to my lips, taste Hebes cup:
Stand firm on deck, when beauties close fight is up.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Lady, your strange habit doth beget
Our pregnant thoughts, even great of much desire,
To be acquaint with your condition.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Good sweet Lady, without more ceremonies,
What country claims your birth, and sweet your name?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: In hope your bounty will extend itself,
In self same nature of fair courtesy,
I will shun all niceness; my name is Florizell,
My country Scythia, I am Amazon,
Cast on this shore by fury of the sea.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Nay faith, sweet creature, we will not vail our names.
It pleased the Font to dip me Rossaline:
That Lady bears the name of Mellida,
The duke of Venice daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, I am obliged to kiss your hand,
By imposition of a now dead man.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Now by my troth, I long beyond all thought,
To know the man; sweet beauty deign his name.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lady, the circumstance is tedious.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Troth not a whit; good fair, let us have it all:
I love not, I, to have a jot left out,
If the tale come from a loved Orator.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Vouchsafe me then your hushed observances.
Vehement in pursuit of strange novelties,
After long travail through the Asian main,
I shipped my hopeful thoughts for Britany;
Longing to view great natures miracle,
The glory of our sex, whose fame doth strike
Remotest ears with adoration.
Sailing some two months with inconstant winds,
We viewed the glistering Venetian forts;
To which we made: when lo, some three leagues off,
We might descry a horrid spectacle:
The issue of black fury strowed the sea,
With tattered carcasses of splitted ships,
Half sinking, burning, floating, topsy turvy.
Not far from these sad ruins of fell rage,
We might behold a creature press the waves;
Senseless he sprawled, all notched with gaping wounds:
To him we made, and (short) we took him up:
The first word that he spake was, Mellida;
And then he swooned.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Ay me

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why sigh you, fair?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Nothing but little humours: good sweet, on.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: His wounds being dressed, and life recovered,
We gan discourse; when lo, the sea grew mad,
His bowels rumbling with wind passion,
Straight swarthy darkness popped out Phoebus eye,
And blurred the jocund face of bright cheeked day;
Whilst curdled fogs masked even darkness brow:
Heaven bade us good night, and the rocks groaned
At the intestine uproar of the main.
Now gusty flaws struck up the very heels
Of our main mast, whilst the keen lightning shot
Through the black bowels of the quaking air:
Straight chops a wave, and in his sliftered paunch
Down falls our ship, and there he breaks his neck:
Which in an instant up was belkt again.
When thus this martyred soul began to sigh;
Give me your hand (quoth he) now do you grasp
The unequal mirror of ragged misery:
Is it not a horrid storm? O, well shaped sweet,
Could your quick eye strike through these gashed wounds ,
You should behold a heart, a heart, fair creature,
Raging more wild than is this frantic sea.
Wilt do me a favour, if thou chance survive?
But visit Venice, kiss the precious white
Of my most; nay all all Epithets are base
To attribute to gracious Mellida
Tell her the spirit of Antonio
Wisheth his last gasp breathed upon her breast.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why weeps soft hearted Florisell?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Alas, the flinty rocks groaned at his plaints.
Tell her (quoth he) that her obdurate sire
Hath cracked his bosom; therewithal he wept,
And thus sighed on. The sea is merciful;
Look how it gapes to bury all my grief:
Well, thou shalt have it, thou shalt be his tomb:
My faith in my love live; in thee, die woe,
Die unmatched anguish, die Antonio:
With that he tottered from the reeling deck,
And down he sunk.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Pleasures body, what makes my Lady weep?

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Nothing, sweet Rossaline, but the air is sharpe.
My fathers Palace, Madam, will be proud
To entertain your presence, if you will deign
To make repose within. Ay me!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lady our fashion is not curious.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Faith all the nobler, it is more generous.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Shall I then know how fortune fell at last,
What succour came, or what strange fate ensued?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Most willingly: but this same court is vast,
And public to the staring multitude.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Sweet Lady, nay good sweet, now by my troth
We will be bedfellows: dirt on complement froth.

body.stage: Exeunt; Rossaline giuing Antonio the way.
Enter Catzo (with a Capon) eating, Dildo following him.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Ha Catzo, your master wants a clean trencher: do you hear?
Balurdo calls for your diminutive attendance.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.l: The belly hath no ears Dildo.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Good pug give me some capon.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: No capon, no not a bit ye smooth bully; capon is no meat for Dildo: milk, milk,ye glibbery urchin, is food for infants.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Upon mine honour

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Your honour with a poh? 'slid, now every Jack an Apes loads his back with the golden coat of honour; every Ass puts on the Lions skin and roars his honour,upon your honour. By my Ladies pantofle, I fear I shall live to hear a Vintners boy cry; it is rich neat Canary, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: My stomach is up.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.l: I think thou art hungry.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: The match of fury is lighted, fastened to the linstock of rage, and will presently set fire to the touch-hole of intemperance, discharging the double culvering of my incensement in the face of thy opprobrious speech.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.l: I will stop the barrel thus; god Dildo, set not fire to the touch-hole.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: My rage is stopped, and I will eat to the health of the fool thy master Castilio.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.l: And I will suck the juice of the capon, to the health of the Idiot thy master Balurdo.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Faith, our masters are like a case of Rapiers sheathed in one scabbard of folly.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: Right dutch blades. But was it not rare sport at the sea battle, whilst rounce robble hobble roared from the ship sides, to view our masters pluck their plumes and drop their feathers, for fear of being men of mark.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: 'Slid (cried Seignior Balurdo) O for Don Bessiclers armour, in the Mirror of Knighthood: what coil is here? O for an armour, Canon proof: O, more cable, more featherbeds, more featherbeds, more cable, till he had as much as my cable hatband, to fence him.

body.stage: Enter Flauia in haste, with a rebato.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.l: Buxom Flauia: can you sing? song, song.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: My sweet Dildo, I am not for you at this time: Madam Rossaline stays for a fresh ruff to appear in the presence: sweet away.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: It will not be so put off, delicate, delicious, spark eyed, sleek skinned, slender wasted, clean legged, rarely shaped.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Who, I will be at all your service another season: nay faith there is reason in all things.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Would I were reason then, that I might be in all things.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.p: The brief and the semiquaver is, we must have the descant you made upon our names, ere you depart.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Faith, the song will seem to come off hardly.

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.l: Troth not a whit, if you seem to come off quickly.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Peart Catzo, knock it lustily then.

body.stage: Enter Forobosco, with two torches: Castilio singing fantastically: Rossaline running a Caranto pase, and Balurdo: Feliche following, wondring at them all.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Make place gentlemen; pages, hold torches, the prince approacheth the presence.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: What squeaking cart wheel have we here? ha?
Make place gentlemen, pages hold torches, the prince approacheth the presence.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Faugh, what a strong scent is here, some body useth to wear socks.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: By this fair candle light, it is not my feet, I never wore socks since I sucked pap.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Savourly put off.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Ha, her wit stings, blisters, galls off the skin with the tart acrimony of her sharpe quickness: by sweetness, she is the very Pallas that flew out of Jupiter's brainpan. Delicious creature, vouchsafe me your service: by the purity of bounty, I shall be proud of such bondage.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I vouchsafe it; be my slave Seignior Balurdo, wilt thou be my servant too?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: O god: forsooth in very good earnest, law, you would make me as a man should say, as a man should say.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: 'Slid sweet beauty, will you deign him your service?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: O, your fool is your only servant. But good Feliche why art thou so sad? a penny for thy thought, man.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: I sell not my thought so cheap: I value my meditation at a higher rate.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: In good sober sadness, sweet mistress, you should have had my thought for a penny: by this crimson Satin that cost eleven shillings, thirteen pence, three pence, half penny a yard, that you should, law.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What was thy thought, good servant?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Marry forsooth, how many strike of peas would feed a hog fat against Christide.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Poh; servant rub out my rheum, it soils the presence.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: By my wealthiest thought, you grace my shoe with an unmeasured honour: I will preserve the soul of it, as a most sacred relic, for this service.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: I will spit in thy mouth, and thou wilt, to grace thee.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: O that the stomach of this queasy age
Digests, or brooks such raw unseasoned gobs,
And vomits not them forth O slavish sots.
Servant quoth you? faugh: if a dog should crave
And beg her service, he should have it straight:
She would give him favours too; to lick her feet,
Or fetch her fan, or some such drudgery:
A good dogs office, which these amourists
Triumph of: it is rare, well give her more Ass,
More sot, as long as dropping of her nose
Is sworn rich pearl by such low slaves as those.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Flauia, attend me to attire me.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: In sad good earnest, sir, you have touched the very bare of naked truth; my silk stocking hath a good gloss, and I thank my planets, my leg is not altogether unpropitiously shaped. There is a word: unpropitiously? I think I shall speak unpropitiously as well as any courtier in Italy.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: So help me your sweet bounty, you have the most graceful presence, applausive elecuty, amazing volubility, polished adornation, delicious affability.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Whop: 'sfoot how he tickles yon trout under the gills you shall see him take him by and by, with groping flattery.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.p: That ever ravished the ear of wonder. By your sweet self, than whom I know not a more exquisite, illustrate, accomplished, pure, respected, adored, observed, precious, real, magnanimous, bounteous: if you have an idle rich cast jerkin, or so, it shall not be cast away, if; ha?here is a forehead, an eye, a head, a hair, that would make a: or if you have any spare pair of silver spurs, I will do you as much right in all kind offices

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Of a kind Parasite

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: As any of my mean fortunes shall be able to

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: As I am true Christian now, thou hast won the spurs

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: For flattery.
O how I hate that same Egyptian louse;
A rotten maggot, that lives by stinking filth
Of tainted spirits: vengeance to such dogs,
That sprout by gnawing senseless carrion.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Gallants, saw you my mistress, the Lady Rossaline?

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: My mistress, the Lady Rossaline, left the presence even now.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: My mistress, the Lady Rossaline, withdrew her gracious aspect even now.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: My mistress, the Lady Rossaline, withdrew her gracious aspect even now.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Well said echo.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: My mistress, and his mistress, and your mistress, and the dogs mistress: precious dear heaven, that
sp.l: lives, to have such rivals.
'slid, I have been searching every private rome,
Corner, and secret angle of the court:
And yet, and yet, and yet she lives concealed.
Good sweet Feliche, tell me how to find
My bright faced mistress out.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Why man, cry out for lantern and candlelight. For it is your only way, to find your bright flaming wench, with your light burning torch: for most commonly, these light creatures live in darkness.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Away you heretic, you will be burnt for

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Go, you amorous hound, follow the sent of your mistress shoe; away.

sp.speaker: Foro.
sp.l: Make a fair presence, boys, advance your lights:
The Princess makes approach.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p:
And please the gods, now in very good deed, law, you shall see me tickle the measures for the heavens.
Do my hangers show?

body.stage: Enter Piero, Antonio, Mellida, Rossaline, Galeatzo, Matzagente, Alberto, and Flauia. As they enter, Feliche, and Castilio make a ranke for the Duke to passe through. Forobosco vshers the Duke to his state: then whilst Piero speaketh his first speach, Mellida is taken by Galeatzo and Matzagente, to daunce; they supporting her: Rossaline, in like maner, by Alberto and Balurdo: Flauia, by Feliche and Castilio.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Beauteous Amazon, sit, and seat your thoughts
In the reposure of most soft content.
Sound music there. Nay daughter, clear your eyes,
From these dull fogs of misty discontent:
Look sprightly girl. What? though Antonio is drowned,
That peevish dotard on thy excellence,
That hated issue of Andrugio:
Yet mayst thou triumph in my victories;
Since, lo, the high borne bloods of Italy
Sue for thy seat of love.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Beauty and youth run descant on loves ground.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Lady, erect your gracious summitry:
Shine in the sphere of sweet affection:
Your eye as heavy, as the heart of night.

sp.speaker: Mell.
Gal.
sp.l: Faith sweet, I will lay thee on the lips for that jest.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: I prithee intrude not on a dead man's right.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: No, but the livings just possession.
Thy lips, and love, are mine.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: You never took seizing on them yet: forbear:
There is not a vacant corner of my heart,
But all is filled with dead Antonios loss.
Then urge no more; O leave to love at all;
It is less disgraceful, not to mount, then fall.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Bright and refulgent Lady, deign your ear:
You see this blade, had it a courtly lip,
It would divulge my valour, plead my love,
Jostle that skipping feeble amourist
Out of your loves seat; I am Matzagent.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Hark thee, I pray thee taint not thy sweet ear
With that sots gabble; By thy beauteous cheek,
He is the flaggingest bulrush that ever drooped
With each slight mist of rain. But with pleased eye
Smile on my courtship.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: What said you sir? alas my thought wax fixed
Upon another object. Good, forbear:
I shall but weep. Ay me, what boots a tear!
Come, come, let us dance. O music thou distillest
More sweetness in us than this jarring world:
Both time and measure from thy strains do breath,
Whilst from the channel of this dirt doth flow
Nothing but timeless grief, unmeasured woe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O how impatience cramps my cracked veins,
And curdles thick my blood, with boiling rage!
O eyes, why leap you not like thunderbolts,
Or canon bullets in my rivals face;

l.foreign: Oy me infeliche misero, o lamenteuol fato!

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: What means the Lady fall upon the ground?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Belike the falling sickness.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I cannot brooke this sight, my thoughts grow wild:
Here lies a wretch, on whom heaven never smiled.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What servant, never a word, and I hear man?
I would shoot some speech forth, to strike the time
With pleasing touch of amorous complement.
Say sweet, what keeps thy mind, what thinkst thou on?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: What is that nothing?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: A woman's constancy.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Good, why, wouldst thou have us sluts, and never shift the vesture of our thoughts? Away for shame.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: O no, thou art too constant to afflict my heart,
Too too firm fixed in unmoved scorn.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Pish, pish; I fixed in unmoved scorn?
Why, I will love thee tonight.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: But whom tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Faith, as the toy puts me in the head.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: And pleased the marble heavens, now would I might be the toy, to put you in the head, kindly to conceit my my my: pray you give in an Epithet for love.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Roaring, roaring.
sp.p: O love thou hast murdered me, made me a shadow, and you hear not Balurdo, but Balurdos ghost.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Can a ghost speak?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Scurvily, as I do.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And walk?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: After their fashion.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: And eat apples?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: In a sort, in their garb.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Prithee Flauia be my mistress.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Your reason, good Feliche?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Faith, I have nineteen mistresses already, and I not much disdain that thou shouldest make up the full score.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: O , I hear you make common places of your mistresses, to perform the office of memory by. Pray you, in ancient times were not those satin hose? In good faith, now they are new died, pinked and scoured, they show as well as if they were new.
sp.l: What, mute Balurdo?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: , in faith, if it were not for printing, and painting, my breech, and your face would be out of reparation.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Aye , an faith, if it were not for printing, and pointing, my breech, and your face would be out of reparation.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Good again, Echo.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Thou art, by nature, too foul to be affected.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: And thou, by Art, too fair to be beloved.
By wits life, most spark spirits, but hard chance.
La ty dine.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Gallants, the night grows old; and downy sleep
Courts us, to entertain his company:
Our tired limbs, bruised in the morning fight,
Entreat soft rest, and gentle hushed repose.
Fill out Greek wines; prepare fresh cresset-light:
We will have a banquet: Princes, then good night.

body.stage: The Cornets sound a Synnet, and the Duke goes out in state. As they are going out, Antonio stayes Mellida: the rest Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What means these scattered looks? why tremble you?
Why quake your thoughts, in your distracted eyes?
Collect your spirits, Madam; what do you see?
Dost not behold a ghost?
Look, look where he stalks, wrapped up in clouds of grief,
Darting his soul, upon thy wondering eyes.
Look, he comes towards thee; see, he stretcheth out
His wretched arms to girt thy loved waste,
With a most wished embrace: seest him not yet?
Nor yet? Ha, Mellida; thou well mayst err:
For look; he walks not like Antonio:
Like that Antonio, that this morning shone,
In glistering habiliments of arms,
To seize his love, spite of her fathers spite:
But like himself, wretched, and miserable,
Banished, forlorn, despairing, struck quite through,
With sinking grief, rolled up in seven-fold doubles
Of plagues, vanquishable: hark, he speaks to thee.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Alas, I cannot hear, nor see him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why? all this night about the room he stalked,
And groaned, and howled, with raging passion,
To view his love (life blood of all his hopes,
Crown of his fortunes) clipped by strangers arms.
Look but behind thee.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: O, Antonio; my Lord, my Love, my

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Leave passion, sweet; for time, place, air, and earth,
Are all our foes: fear, and be jealous; fair,
Let us fly.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Dear heart; ha, whether?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, it is no matter whether, but let us fly.
Ha! now I think of it, I have never a home:
No father, friend, no country to embrace
These wretched limbs: the world, the All that is,
Is all my foe: a prince not worth a doit:
Only my head is hoisted to high rate,
Worth twenty thousand double Pistolets,
To him that can but strike it from these shoulders.
But come sweet creature, thou shalt be my home;
My father, country, riches, and my friend:
My all, my soul; and thou and I will live:
(Let us think like what) and thou and I will live
Like unmatched mirrors of calamity.
The jealous ear of night eavesdrops our talk.
Hold thee, there is a jewel; and look thee, there is a note
That will direct thee when, where, how to fly;
Bid me adieu.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Farewell bleak misery.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stay sweet, let us kiss before you go .

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Farewell dear soul.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Farewell my life, my heart.

body.stage: Enter Andrugio in armour, Lucio with a sheepeheard gowne in his hand, and a Page.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Is not yon gleam, the shuddering morn that flakes,
With silver tincture, the east verge of heaven?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I think it is, so please your excellence.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Away, I have no excellence to please.
Prithee observe the custom of the world,
That only flatters greatness, States exalts.
And please my excellence O Lucio.
Thou hast been ever held respected dear,
Even precious to Andrugios in most love.
Good, flatter not. Nay, if thou givest not faith
That I am wretched, O read that, read that.

body.stage: Piero Sforza, to the Italian Princes, fortune

sp.p: Excellent, the just overthrow, Andrugio took in the Venetian gulf, hath so assured the Genowaies of the justice of his cause, and the hatefulness of his person, that they have banished him and all his family: and, for confirmation of their peace with us , have vowed, that if he, or his son , can be attached, to send us both their heads. We therefore, by force of our united league, forbid you to harbour him, or his blood: but if you apprehend his person, we entreat you to send him, or his head, to us . For we vow by the honour of our blood, to recompense any man that bringeth his head, with twenty thousand double Pistolets, and the endearing to our choicest love .
sp.l: From Venice Piero Sforza

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: My thoughts are fixed in contemplation
Why this huge earth, this monstrous animal,
That eats her children, should not have eyes andears.
Philosophy maintains that Nature is wise,
And forms no useless or unperfect thing.
Did Nature make the earth, or the earth Nature?
For earthly dirt makes all things, makes the man,
Molds me up honour; and like a cunning Dutchman,
Paints me a puppet even with seeming breath,
And gives a sot appearance of a soul,
Go to,go to; thou liest Philosophy.
Nature forms things unperfect, useless, vain
Why made she not the earth with eyes and ears?
That she might see desert, and hear men's plaints:
That when a soul is splitted, sunk with grief,
He might fall thus, upon the breast of earth;
And in her ear, halloo his misery:
Exclaiming thus. O thou all bearing earth,
Which men do gape for, till thou crammest their mouths,
And chokest their throats with dust: O chance thy breast,
And let me sink into thee. Look who knocks;
Andrugio calls. But O, she is deaf and blind.
A wretch, but lean relief on earth can find.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Sweet Lord, abandon passion, and disarm.
Since by the fortune of the tumbling sea,
We are rolled up, upon the Venice marsh,
Let us clip all fortune,lest more lowering fate

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: More lowering fate? O Lucio, choke that breath.
Now I defy chance. Fortunes brow hath frowned,
Even to the utmost wrinkle it can bend:
Her venom is spit. Alas, what country rests,
What son, what comfort that she can deprive?
Triumphs not Venice in my overthrow?
Gapes not my native country for my blood?
Lies not my son tombed in the swelling main?
And yet more lowering fate? There is nothing left
Unto Andrugio, but Andrugio:
And that nor mischief, force, distress, nor hell can take.
Fortune my fortunes, not my mind shall shake.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Speak like yourself: but give me leave, my Lord,
To wish your safety. If you are but seen,
Your arms display you; therefore put them off,
And take

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Wouldst thou have me go unarmed among my foes?
Being besieged by passion, entering lists,
To combat with despair and mighty grief:
My soul beleaguered with the crushing strength
Of sharpe impatience. Ha Lucio, go unarmed?
Come soul, resume the valour of thy birth;
Myself, myself will dare all opposites:
I will muster forces, an unvanquished power:
Cornets of horse shall press the ungrateful earth;
This hollow wombed mass shall inly groan,
And murmur to sustain the weight of arms:
Ghastly amazement, with upstarted hair,
Shall hurry on before, and usher us,
Whilst trumpets clamour, with a sound of death.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Peace, good my Lord, your speech is all too light.
Alas, survey your fortunes, look what is left
Of all your forces, and your utmost hopes?
A weak old man, a Page, and your poor self.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Andrugio lives, and a fair cause of arms,
Why that is an army all invincible.
He who hath that, hath a battalion
Royal, armour of proof, huge troops of barbed steeds,
Main squares of pikes, millions of harquebus.
O, a fair cause stands firm, and will abide.
Legions of Angels fight upon her side.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Then, noble spirit, slide in strange disguise,
Unto some gracious Prince, and sojourn there,
Till time, and fortune give revenge firm means.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No, I will not trust the honour of a man:
Gold is grown great, and makes perfidiousness
A common water in most Princes Courts:
He is in the check-roll: I will not trust my blood;
I know none breathing, but will cog a die
For twenty thousand double Pistolets.
How goes the time?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I saw no sun today.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No sun will shine, where poor Andrugio breaths.
My soul grows heavy: boy let us have a song:
We will sing yet, faith, even despite of fate.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: It is a good boy, and by my troth, well sung.
O, and thou feltest my grief, I warrant thee,
Thou wouldst have struck division to the height;
And made the life of music breath: hold boy: why so?
For Gods sake call me not Andrugio,
That I may soon forget what I have been.
For heavens name, name not Antonio;
That I may not remember he was mine.
Well, ere yon sun set, I will show myself myself,
Worthy my blood. I was a Duke;that is all.
No matter whether, but from whence we fall.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Castilio? Alberto? Balurdo? none up?
Forobosco? Flattery, nor thou up yet:
Then there is no Courtier stirring:that is firm truth?
I cannot sleep: Feliche seldom rests
In these court lodgings. I have walked all night,
To see if the nocturnal court delights
Could force me envy their felicity:
And by plain troth; I will confess plain troth:
I envy nothing, but the Trauense light.
O, had it eyes, and ears, and tongues, it might
See sport, hear speech of most strange surquedries.
O, if that candle-light were made a Poet,
He would prove a rare firking Satirist,
And draw the core forth of imposthumed sin.
Well, I thank heaven yet, that my content
Can envy nothing, but poor candle-light.
As for the other glistering copper spangs,
That glisten in the attire of the Court,
Praise God, I either hate, or pity them.
Well, here I will sleep till that the scene of up
Is past at Court. O calm hushed rich content,
Is there a being blessedness without thee?
How soft thou downest the couch where thou dost rest,
Nectar to life, thou sweet Ambrosian feast.

body.stage: Enter Castilio and his Page: Castilio with a casting bottle of sweete water in his hand, sprinkling himselfe.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Am not I a most sweet youth now?

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.l: Yes, when your throat is perfumed; your very words
Do smell of Amber greece. O stay sir, stay;
Sprinkle some sweet water to your shoes heels,
That your mistress may swear you have a sweet foot.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Good, very good, very passing passing good.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: 'sfoot, what treble minikin squeaks there, ha? good? very good, very very good?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I will warble to the delicious concave of my
Mistress ear: and strike her thoughts with
The pleasing touch of my voice.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Feliche, health, fortune, mirth, and wine,

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: To thee my love divine.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: I drink to thee, sweating.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Plague on thee for an Ass.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Now thou hast seen the Court; by the perfection of it, dost not envy it?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: I wonder it doth not envy me.
Why man, I have been borne upon the spirits wings,
The souls swift Pegasus, the fantasy:
And from the height of contemplation,
Have viewed the feeble joints men totter on.
I envy none; but hate, or pity all.
For when I view, with an intentive thought,
That creature fair; but proud; him rich, but sot:
The other witty; but unmeasured arrogant:
Him great; yet boundless in ambition:
Him high borne; but of base life: the other feared;
Yet feared fears, and fears most, to be most loved:
Him wise; but made a fool for public use:
The other learned, but self opinionate:
When I discourse all these, and see myself
Nor fair, nor rich, nor witty, great, nor feared:
Yet amply suited, with all full content:
Lord, how I clap my hands, and smooth my brow,
Rubbing my quiet bosom, tossing up
A grateful spirit to omnipotence!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Ha, ha: but if thou knewest my happiness,
Thou wouldst even grate away thy soul to dust,
In envy of my sweet beatitude:
I cannot sleep for kisses; I cannot rest
For Ladies letters, that importune me
With such unused vehemence of love,
Straight to solicit them, that

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Confusion seize me, but I think thou liest.
Why should I not be sought too then as well?
'sfoot, methinks , I am as like a man.
Troth, I have a good head of hair, a cheek
Not as yet waned; a leg, faith, in the full.
I have not a red beard, take not tobacco much:
And 'Slid, for other parts of manliness

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Pew waw, you never accourted them in pomp:
Put your good parts in presence, graciously.
Have , and you had, why they would have come off , sprung
To your arms: and sued, and prayed, and vowed;
And opened all their sweetness to your love.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: There are a number of such things, as then
Have often urged me to such loose belief:
But 'Slid you all do lie, you all do lie.
I have put on good clothes, and smudged my face,
Struck a fair wench, with a smart speaking eye:
Courted in all sorts, blunt, and passionate;
Had opportunity put them to the ah:
And, by this light, I find them wondrous chaste,
Impregnable; perchance a kiss, or so:
But for the rest, O most inexorable.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Nay then i'faith, prithee look here.

body.stage: Shewes him the superscription of a seeming Letter.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: To her most esteemed, loved, and generous servant, Seignior Castilto Balthazar.
Prithee from whom comes this? faith I must see.
From her that is devoted to thee, in most private sweets of love; Rossaline.
Nay, god is my comfort, I must see the rest;
I must, sans ceremony, faith I must.

body.stage: Feliche takes away the letter by force.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: O, you spoil my ruff, unset my hair; good away.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Item for strait canvas, thirteen pence, half penny. Item for an ell and a half of taffeta to cover your old canvas doublet, fourteen shillings, and three pence. So light, this a tailors bill.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: In sooth it is the outside of her letter; on which I took the copy of a tailors bill.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: But it is not crossed, I am sure of that. Lord have mercy on him, his credit hath given up the last gasp. Faith I will leave him; for he looks as melancholy as a wench the first night she

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Honest musk-cod, it will not be so stitched together; take that, and that, and belie no Ladies love : swear no more by Iesu: this Madam, that Lady; hence go, forswear the presence, travail three years to bury this bastinado: avoid, puff paste, avoid.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: And tell not my Lady mother. Well, as I am true gentleman, if she had not wild me on her blessing, not to spoil my face; if I could not find in my heart to fight, would I might never eat a Potato pie more.

body.stage: Enter Balurdo, backward; Dildo following him with a looking glasse in one hand, and a candle in the other hand: Flauia following him backward, with a looking glasse in one hand, and a candle in the other; Rossaline following her. Balurdo and Rossaline stand setting of faces: and so the Sceane begins.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: More fool, more rare fools O, for time and place, long enough, and large enough, to act these fools! Here might be made a rare Scene of folly, if the plot could bear it.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: By the sugar candy sky, hold up the glass higher, that I may see to swear in fashion. O, one loof more would have made them shine; gods necks, they would have shone like my mistress brow. Even so the Duke frowns for all this Cursed world: O that girn kills, it kills. By my golden What is the richest thing about me?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Your teeth.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: By my golden teeth, hold up; that I may put in: hold up, I say, that I may see to put on my gloves.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: O, delicious sweet cheeked master, if you discharge but one glance from the level of that set face: O, you will strike a wench; you will make any wench love you.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: By Iesu, I think I am as elegant a Courtier, as
How likest thou my suite?

sp.speaker: Catz.
sp.l: All, beyond all, no paregal: you are wondered at, for an ass.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Well, Dildo, no christen creature shall know hereafter, what I will do for thee heretofore.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Here wants a little white, Flauia.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.p: Aye , but master, you have one little fault; you sleep open mouthed.

sp.speaker: Ba.
Fla.
sp.p: By my troth, you look as like the princess, now Aye , but her lip is lip is a little redder, a very little redder: but by the help of Art, or Nature, ere I change my periwig, mine shall be as red

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: O, Aye , that face, that eye, that smile, that writhing of your body, that wanton dandling of your fan, becomes prettily, so sweetly, it is even the goodest Lady that breathes, the most amiable Faith the fringe of your satin petticoat is ripped. Good faith madam, they say you are the most bounteous Lady to your women, that ever O most delicious beauty Good Madam let me kith it.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Rare sport, rare sport! A female fool, and a female flatterer.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Body a me, the Duke: away the glass.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Take up your paper, Rossaline.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Not mine, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Not yours, my Lady? I will see what it is.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: And how does my sweet mistress? O Lady dear, even as it is an old say, It is an old horse can neither wehee, nor wag his tail: even so do I hold my set face still: even so, it is a bad courtier that can neither discourse, nor blow his nose.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Meet me at Abrahams, the Jews, where I bought my Amazons disguise. A ship lies in the port, ready bound for England; make haste, come private.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Antonio, Forobosco, Alberto, Feliche, Castilio, Balurdo? run, keep the Palace, post to the ports, go to my daughters chamber: whether now? scud to the Jews, stay, run to the gates, stop the gondolets, let none pass the marsh, do all at once. Antonio? his head, his head. Keep you the Court, the rest stand still, or run, or go, or shout, or search, or scud, or call, or hang, or do do do, su su su, something: I know not who who who, what I do do do, nor who who who, where I am.

l.foreign: O trista traditriche, rea, ribalda fortuna,
Negando mi vindetta mi causa fera morte.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Ha ha ha. I could break my spleen at his impatience.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Alma and gratiosa fortuna siate fauorevole,
Et fortunati siano vuoti del mia dulce Mellida, Mellida.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Alas Antonio, I have lost thy note.
A number mount my stairs; I will straight return.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Antonio,
Be not affright, sweet Prince; appease thy fear,
Buckle thy spirits up, put all thy wits
In wimble action, or thou art surprised.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I care not.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Art mad, or desperate? or

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Both, both, all, all: I prithee let me lie;
Spite of you all, I can, and I will die.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: You are distraught; O, this is madness breath.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Each man take hence life, but no man death:
He is a good fellow, and keeps open house:
A thousand thousand ways lead to his gate,
To his wide mouthed porch: when niggard life
Hath but one little, little wicket through.
We wring ourselves into this wretched world,
To pule, and weep, exclaim, to curse and rail,
To fret, and ban the fates, to strike the earth
As I do now. Antonio, curse thy birth,
And die.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Nay, heaven is my comfort, now you are perverse;
You know I always loved you; prithee live.
Wilt thou strike dead thy friends, draw mourning tears

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Alas, Feliche, I have never a friend;
No country, father, brother, kinsman left
To weep my fate, or sigh my funeral:
I roll but up and down, and fill a seat
In the dark cave of dusky misery.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Fore heaven, the Duke comes: hold you, take my key,
Slink to my chamber, look you; that is it:
There shall you find a suite I wore at sea:
Take it, and slip away. Nay, precious,
If you will be peevish, by this light, I will swear,
Thou railedest upon thy love before thou diedest,
And called her strumpet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She will not credit thee.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Tut, that is all one: I will defame thy love;
And make thy dead trunk held in vile regard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wilt needs have it so? why then Antonio,

l.foreign: Viue esperanza, in despetto aell fato.

body.stage: Enter Piero, Galeatzo, Matzagente, Forobosco, Balurdo, and Castilio, with weapons.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: O, my sweet Princes, was it not bravely found?
Even there I found the note, even there it lay.
I kiss the place for joy, that there it lay.
This way he went, here let us make a stand:
I will keep this gate myself: O gallant youth!
I will drink carouse unto your countries health,

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Even in Antonio's skull.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Lord bless us: his breath is more fearful than a Sergeants voice, when he cries; I arrest.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stop Antonio, keep, keep Antonio.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Where, where man, where?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here, here: let me me pursue him down the marsh.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Hold, there is my signet, take a gondolet:
Bring me his head, his head, and by mine honour,
I will make thee the wealthiest Mariner that breathes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will sweat my blood out, till I have him safe.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Speak heartily i'faith, good Mariner.
O, we will mount in triumph: soon, at night,
I will set his head up. Let us think where.

sp.speaker: Ba.

body.stage: Enter Mellida in Pages attire, dauncing.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Sprightly, i'faith. In troth he is somewhat like
My daughter Mellida but alas poor soul,
Her honour heels, god knows, are half so light.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Escaped I am, spite of my fathers spite.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Ho, this will warm my bosom ere I sleep.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O my Lord, your daughter.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Aye, Aye , my daughter is safe enough, I warrant thee.
This vengeance on the boy will lengthen out
My days unmeasuredly.
It shall be chronicled, time to come;
Piero Sforza slew Andrugio's son.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Aye , but my Lord, your daughter.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Aye, Aye , my good wench, she is safe enough.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: O, then, my Lord, you know she is run away.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Run away, away, how run away?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: She is vanished in an instant, none knows whether.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Pursue, pursue, fly, run, post, scud away.

body.stage: Feliche sing; And was not good king Salomon.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Fly, call, run, row, ride, cry, shout, hurry, haste:
Haste, hurry, shout, cry, ride, row, run, call, fly
Backward and forward, every way about.

l.foreign: Maldetta fortuna shy condura sorta
Che faro, che diro, pur fugir tanto mal!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: It was you that struck me even now: was it not?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: It was I that struck you even now.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: You bastinadoed me, I take it. I

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: I bastinadoed you, and you took it.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Faith sir, I have the richest Tobacco in the court for you; I would be glad to make you satisfaction, if I have wronged you. I would not the Sun should set upon your anger; give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Content faith, so thou wilt breed no more such lies.
I hate not man, but man's lewd qualities.

body.stage: Enter Antonio, in his sea gowne running.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stop, stop Antonio, stay Antonio.
Vain breath, vain breath, Antonio is lost;
He cannot find himself, not seize himself.
Alas, this that you see, is not Antonio,
His spirit hovers in Piero's Court,
Hurling about his agile faculties,
To apprehend the sight of Mellida:
But poor, poor soul, wanting apt instruments
To speak or see, stands dumb and blind, sad spirit,
Rolled up in gloom clouds as black as air,
Through which the rusty coach of Night is drawn:
It is so, I will give you instance that it is so.
Conceit you me. As having clasped a rose
Within my palm, the rose being taken away,
My hand retains a little breath of sweet:
So may man's trunk; his spirit slipped away,
Holds still a faint perfume of his sweet guest.
It is so; for when discursive powers fly out,
And rome in progress, through the bounds of heaven,
The soul itself gallops along with them,
As chieftain of this winged troop of thought,
Whilst the dull lodge of spirit standeth waste,
Until the soul return from
What was it I said?
O, this is naught, but speckling melancholy.
I have been
That Morpheus tender skimp
Cousin germane
Bear with me good
Mellida: clod upon clod thus fall.
Hell is beneath; yet heaven is over all.

body.stage: Enter Andrugio, Lucio, Cole, and Norwod.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Come Lucio, let us go eat: what hast thou got?
Roots, roots? alas, they are seeded, new cut up.
O, thou hast wronged Nature, Lucio:
But boots not much; thou but pursuest the world,
That cuts off virtue, before it comes to growth,
Lest it should seed, and so overrun her son,
Dull purblind error. Give me water, boy.
There is no poison in it I hope, they say
That lukes in massy plate: and yet the earth
Is so infected with a general plague,
That he is most wise, that thinks there is no man fool:
Right prudent, that esteems no creature just:
Great policy the least things to mistrust.
Give me Assay How we mock greatness now!

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A strong conceit is rich, so most men deem:
If not to be, it is comfort yet to seem.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Why man, I never was a Prince till now.
It is not the bared pate, the bended knees,
Guilt tipstaves, Tyrrian purple, chairs of state,
Troops of pied butterflies, that flutter still
In greatness summer, that confirm a prince:
It is not the unsavoury breath of multitudes,
Shouting and clapping, with confused din;
That makes a Prince. No Lucio, he is a king,
A true right king, that dares do aught, save wrong,
Fears nothing mortal, but to be unjust,
Who is not blown up with the flattering puffs
Of spongy Sycophants: Who stands unmoved,
Despite the jostling of opinion:
Who can enjoy himself, maugre the throng
That strive to press his quiet out of him:
Who sits upon Jove's footstool, as I do,
Adoring, not affecting, majesty:
Whose brow is wreathed with the silver crown
Of clear content: this, Lucio, is a king.
And of this empire, every man is possessed,
That is worth his soul.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My Lord, the Genowaies had wont to say

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Name not the Genowaies: that very word
Unkings me quite, makes me vile passions slave.
O, you that made open the glibbery Ice
Of vulgar favour, view Andrugio.
Was never Prince with more applause confirmed,
With louder shouts of triumph launched out
Into the surgy main of government:
Was never Prince with more despite cast out,
Left shipwrecked, banished, on more guiltless ground.
O rotten props of the crazed multitude,
How you still double, falter, under the lightest chance
That strains your veins. Alas, one battle lost,
Your whorish love, your drunken healths, your hoots and shouts,
Your smooth God saves us, and all your devils last
That tempts our quiet, to your hell of throngs.
Spit on me Lucio, for I am turned slave
Observe how passion domineers over me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: No wonder, noble Lord, having lost a son,
A country, crown, and

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Aye Lucio, having lost a son, a son,
A country, house, crown, son. O lares, misereri lares.
Which shall I first deplore? My son, my son,
My dear sweet boy, my dear Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Antonio?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Aye , echo, Aye ; I mean Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Antonio, who means Antonio?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Where art? what art? knowest thou Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Lives he?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Where lies he dead?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Art thou Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I think I am.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Dost thou but think? What, dost not know thyself?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He is a fool that thinks he knows himself.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Upon thy faith to heaven,give thy name.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I were not worthy of Andrugio's blood,
If I denied my name is Antonio.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I were not worthy to be called thy father,
If I denied my name Andrugio.
And dost thou live? O, let me kiss thy cheek,
And dew thy brow with trickling drops of joy.
Now heavens will be done: for I have lived
To see my joy, my son Antonio.
Give me thy hand; now fortune do thy worst,
His blood, that lapped thy spirit in the womb,
Thus (in his love) will make his arms thy tomb.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Bless not the body with your twining arms,
Which is accursed of heaven. O, what black sin
Hath been committed by our ancient house,
Whose scalding vengeance lights upon our heads,
That thus the world, and fortune casts us out,
As loathed objects, ruins branded slaves.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Do not expostulate the heavens will:
But, O, remember to forget thyself:
Forget remembrance what thou once hast been.
Come, creep with me from out this open air.
Even trees have tongues, and will betray our life.
I am araising of our house, my boy:
Which fortune will not envy, it is so mean,
And like the world (all dirt) there shalt thou rip
The inwards of thy fortunes, in mine ears,
Whilst I sit weeping, blind with passions tears:
Then I will begin, and we will such order keep,
That one shall still tell griefs, the other weep.

body.stage: Exit Andrugio, leauing Antonio, and his Page.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will follow you. Boy, prithee stay a little.
Thou hast had a good voice, if this cold marsh,
Wherein we lurk, have not corrupted it.
sp.stage: Enter Mellida, standing out of sight, in her Pages suite.
sp.l: I prithee sing, but sirrah (mark you me)
Let each note breath the heart of passion,
The sad extracture of extremest grief.
Make me a strain; speak, groaning like a bell,
That tolls departing souls.
Breath me a point that may enforce me weep,
To wring my hands, to break my cursed breast,
Rave, and exclaim, lie grovelling on the earth,
Straight start up frantic, crying, Mellida.
Sing but, Antonio hath lost Mellida.
And thou shalt see me (like a man possessed)
Howl out such passion, that even this brinish marsh
Will squeeze out tears, from out his spongy cheeks,
The rocks even groan, and
prithee, prithee sing:
Or I shall never have done when I am in.
It is harder for me end, than to begin.
sp.stage: The boy runnes a note, Antonio breakes it.
sp.l: For look thee boy, my grief that hath no end,
I may begin to plain, but prithee sing.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Heaven keep you sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Heaven keep you from me, sir.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: I must be acquainted with you, sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wherefore? Art thou infected with misery,
Seared with the anguish of calamity?
Art thou true sorrow, hearty grief, canst weep?
I am not for thee if thou canst not rave,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fall flat on the ground, and thus exclaim on heaven;
O trifling Nature, why inspiredest thou breath

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Stay sir, I think you named Mellida.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Knowest thou Mellida?

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hast thou seen Mellida?

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then hast thou seen the glory of her sex,
The music of Nature, the unequalled lustre
Of unmatched excellence, the united sweet
Of heavens graces, the most adored beauty,
That ever struck amazement in the world.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: You seem to love her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With my very soul.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: She will not requite it: all her love is fixed
Upon a gallant, on Antonio,
The Duke of Genoas son. I was her Page:
And often as I waited, she would sigh;
O, dear Antonio; and to strengthen thought,
Would clip my neck, and kiss, and kiss me thus.
Therefore leave loving her: fa, faith methinks ,
Her beauty is not half so ravishing
As you discourse of; she hath a freckled face,
A lowe forehead, and a lumpish eye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O heaven, that I should hear such blasphemy.
Boy, rogue, thou liest, and
Spauento dell mio core dolce Mellida,

l.foreign: Di graua morte restoro vero dolce Mellida,
Celesta saluatrice sovrana Mellida

sp.l: Del mio sperar; trofeo vero Mellida.

l.foreign: Diletta and soaue anima mia Antonio,
Godeuole belezza cortese Antonio.
Signior mio and virginal amore bell' Antonio
Gusto delli mei sensi, car' Antonio.
O suamisce il cor in vn soaue baccio,
Murono i sensi nel desiato dessio:
Nel Cielo puo lesser belta pia chiara.
Nel mondo pol esser belta pia chiara?
Dammi vn baccio da quella bocca beata,
Bassiammi, coglier l'aura odorata
Che in sua neggia in quello dolce labra.

sp.speaker: Mel.

l.foreign: Dammi pimpero del tuo gradit' amore
Che beame, cosempiterno honore,
Cosi, cosi mi conuerra morir.

sp.l: Good, sweet, scout over the marsh: for my heart trembles
At every little breath that strikes my ear,
When thou returnest: and I will discourse
How I deceived the Court: then thou shall tell
How thou escapedest the watch:we will point our speech
With amorous kissing, kissing comas, and even suck
The liquid breath from out each others lips.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dull clod, no man but such sweet favour clips.
I go, and yet my panting blood persuades me stay.
Turn coward in her sight? away, away.
sp.p: I think confusion of Babel is fallen upon these lovers, that they change their language; but I fear me, my master having but fained the person of a woman, hath got their unfeigned imperfection, and is grown double tongued: as for Mellida, she were no woman, if she could not yield strange language. But howsoever, if I should sit in judgment, it is an error easier to be pardoned by the auditors, than excused by the authors; and yet some private respect may rebate the edge of the keener censure.

body.stage: Enter Piero, Castilio, Matzagente, Forobosco, Feliche, Galeatzo, Balurdo, and his Page, at another dore.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: This way she took: search, my sweet gentlemen. How now Balurdo, canst thou meet with anybody?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: As I am true gentleman, I made my horse sweat, that he hath never a dry thread on him: and I can meet with no living creature, but men and beasts. In good sadness, I would have sworn I had seen Mellida even now: for I saw a thing stir under a hedge, and I peeped, and I spied a thing: and I peered, and I twired underneath: and truly a right wise man might have been deceived: for it was

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: What, in the name of heaven?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: A dun cow.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: She had never a kettle on her head?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Boy, didst thou see a young Lady pass this way?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Why speak you not?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Gods necks, proud elf, give the Duke reverence, stand bare with a
Whogh! heavens bless me: Mellida, Mellida.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Where man, where?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Turned man, turned man: women wear the breaches, lo here.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Light and unduteous! kneel not, peevish elf,
Speak not, entreat not, shame unto my house,
Curse to my honour. Where is Antonio?
Thou traitoress to my hate, what is he shipped
For England now? well whimpering harlot, hence.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Good father

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Good me no goods. Seest thou that sprightly youth? ere thou canst term tomorrow morning old, thou shalt call him thy husband, Lord and love.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Aye me.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Blurt on your Ay-me's, guard her safely hence.
Drag her away, I will be your guard tonight.
Young Prince, mount up your spirits, and prepare
To solemnise your Nuptials eve with pomp.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: The time is scant: now nimble wits appear:
Phoebus begins gleam, the welkin is clear.

body.stage: Exeunt all, but Balurdo and his Page.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Now nimble wits appear:I will myself appear,
Balurdo's self, that in quick wit doth surpass,
Will show the substance of a complete

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Ass, ass.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: I will mount my courser, and most gallantly prick

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Gallantly prick is too long, and stands hardly in the verse, sir.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I will speak pure rhyme, and will so bravely prank it, that I will toss love like a prank, prank it: a rhyme for prank it?

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Blank it.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: That I will toss love, like a dog in a blanket: ha ha, indeed law. I think, ha ha, I think ha ha, I think I shall tickle the Muses. And I strike it not dead, say, thou art an arrant sot.

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: Balurdo, thou art an arrant sot.

body.stage: Enter Andrugio and Antonio wreathed together, Lucio.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Now, come united force of chap fallen death:
Come, power of fretting anguish, leave distress.
O, thus enfolded, we have breasts of proof,
Against all the venomed stings of misery.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Father, now I have an antidote,
Against all the poison that the world can breath.
My Mellida, my Mellida doth bless
This bleak waste with her presence. How now boy,
Why dost thou weep? alas, where is Mellida?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Aye me, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: A sodden horror doth invade my blood,
My sinews tremble, and my panting heart
Scuds round about my bosom to go out,
Dreading the assailant, horrid passion.
O, be no tyrant, kill me with one blow.
Speak quickly, briefly boy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Her father found, and seized her, she is gone.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Son, heat thy blood, be not froze up with grief.
Courage, sweet boy, sink not beneath the weight
Of crushing mischief. O where is thy dauntless heart
Thy fathers spirit I renounce thy blood,
If thou forsake thy valour.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: See how his grief speaks in his slow paced steps:
Alas, it is more than he can utter, let him go.
Dumb solitary path best sureth woe.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Give me my arms, my armour Lucio.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Dear Lord, what means this rage, when lacking use
Scarce safes your life, will you in armour rise?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Fortune fears valour, presseth cowardice.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Then valour gets applause, when it hath place,
And means to blaze it.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Nunquam potest non esse.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Patience, my Lord, may bring your ills some end.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: What patience, friend, can ruined hopes attend?
Come, let me die like old Andrugio:
Worthy my birth. O blood true honoured graves
Are far more blessed than base life of slaves.

body.stage: Enter Balurdo, a Painter with two pictures, and Dildo.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And are you a painter sir, can you draw, can you draw?

sp.speaker: Pay.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Indeed law? now so can my fathers fore-horse. And are these the workmanship of your hands?

sp.speaker: Payn.
sp.l: I did limn them.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Limn them? a good word, limn them: whose picture is this? Anno Dominies 1599. Believe me, master Anno Dominies was a good settled age when you limned him. 1599. years old? Let us see the other. Etatis sua 24. byrLady he is somewhat younger. Belike master Etatis sua was Anno Dominies son.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Is not your master a

sp.speaker: Dil.
sp.l: He hath a little proclivity to him

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Proclivity, good youth? I thank you for your courtly proclivity.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Approach good sir. I did send for you to draw me a devise, an Impresa, by Sinecdoche a Mott. By Phoebus crimson taffeta mantle, I think I speak as melodiously, look you sir, how think you of it? I would have you paint me, for my device, a good fat leg of ewe mutton, swimming in stewed broth of plums (boy keel your mouth, it runs over) and the word shall be; Hold my dish, whilst I spill my pottage. Sure, in my conscience, it would be the most sweet device, now.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: It would sent of kitchen stuff too much.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Gods necks, now I remember me, I have
sp.p: the rarest devise in my head that ever breathed. Can you paint me a drivelling reeling song, and let the word be, Uh.

sp.speaker: Payn.
sp.l: A belch.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: O, no no: Uh, paint me uh, or nothing.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: It cannot be done sir, but by a seeming kind of drunkenness.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And if you will my true lover be,
Come follow me to the green wood.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: O Lord, sir, I cannot make a picture sing.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Why? Slid, I have seen painted things sing as sweet:
But I have it will tickle it, for a conceit i'faith.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: O dear Feliche, give me thy device.
How shall I purchase love of Rossaline.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: 'Swill, flatter her soundly.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Her love is such, I cannot flatter her:
But with my utmost vehemence of speech,
I have adored her beauties.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Hast writ good moving unaffected rhymes to her.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: O, yes, Feliche, but she scorns my writ.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Hast thou presented her with sumptuous gifts?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: Alas, my fortunes are too weak to offer them.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: O, then I have it, I will tell thee what to do.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: What, good Feliche?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Go and hang thyself, I say,go hang thy self,
If that thou canst not give, go hang thyself:
I will rhyme thee dead, or verse thee to the rope.
How thinkst thou of a Poet that sung thus;

l.foreign: Munera sola pacant, sola addunt muner a formam:
Munere solicites Pallada, Cypris erit.
Munera, munera.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.l: I will go and breath my woes unto the rocks,
And spend my grief upon the deafest seas.
I will weep my passion to the senseless trees,
And load most solitary air with plaints.
For woods, trees, sea, or rocky Appenine,
Is not so ruthless as my Rossaline.
Farewell dear friend, expect no more of me,
Here ends my part, in this loves Comedy.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Now master Balurdo, whether are you going, ha?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Seignior Feliche, how do you faith, and by my troth, how do you?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Whether art thou going, bully?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: And as heaven help me, how do you?
How, do you i'faith he?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Whether art going man?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: O god, to the Court, I will be willing to give you grace and good countenance, if I may but see you in the presence.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: O to court? farewell.

sp.speaker: Ba.
