sp.p: If you see one in a yellow taffeta doublet, cut upon carnation valure, a green hat, a blue pair of velvet hose, a gilt rapier, and an orange tawny pair of worsted silk stockings, that is I, that is I.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Very good, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Ho, you shall know me as easily, I have bought me a new green feather with a red sprig, you shall see my wrought shirt hang out at my breeches, you shall know me.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Very good, very good, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Marry in the mask it will be somewhat hard. But if you hear anybody speak so wittily, that he makes all the room laugh; that is I, that is I. Farewell good Seignior.

body.stage: Enter Forobosco, Castilio, a boy carying a gilt harpe: Piero, Mellida in night apparrell, Rossaline, Flauia, two Pages.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Advance the musics prize, now capering wits,
Rise to your highest mount; let choice delight
Garland the brow of this triumphant night.
'Sfoot, he sits like Lucifer himself .

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Good sweet Duke, first let their voices strain for musics price. Give me the golden harp: faith with your favour, I will be umpiress.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Sweet niece content: boys clear your voice and sing.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: By this gould, I had rather have a servant with a short nose, and a thin hair, than have such a high stretched minikin voice.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Fair niece, your reason?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: By the sweet of love, I should fear extremely that he were an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Spark spirit, how like you his voice?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Spark spirit, how like you his voice?
sp.p: So help me, youth, thy voice squeaks like a dry cork shoe: come, come, let us hear the next.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Trust me, a good strong mean, Well sung my boy.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Hold, hold, hold: are ye blind, could you not see my voice coming for the harp. And I knock not division on the head, take hence the harp, make me a slip, and let me go but for nine pence. Sir strike up for master Balurdo.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Judgement gentlemen, judgement. Was it not above line?
I appeal to your mouths that heard my song.
Do me right, and dub me knight Balurdo

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Kneel down, and I will dub thee knight of the golden harp.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Indeed law, do, and I will make you Lady of the silver fiddlestick,

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Come, kneel, kneel.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: My troth, I thank you, it hath never a whistle in it

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Nay, good sweet cuz raise up your drooping eyes, and I were at the point of To have and to hold, from this day forward, I would be ashamed to look thus lumpish. What my pretty Cuz, it is but the loss of an odd maidenhead: shall us dance? thou art so sad, hark in mine ear. I was about to say, but I will forbear.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: I come, I come, more than most honeysuckle sweet Ladies, pine not for my presence, I will return in pomp. Well spoke sir Ieffrey Balurdo. As I am a true knight, I feel honourable eloquence begin to grope me already.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Faith, mad niece, I wonder when thou wilt marry?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Faith, kind uncle, when men abandon jealousy, forsake taking of Tobacco, and cease to wear their beards so rudely long. O , to have a husband with a mouth continually smoking, with a bush of furs on the ridge of his chin, ready still to slop into his foaming chaps; ah,it is more than most intolerable.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.p: Nay faith, sweet niece, I was mighty strong in thought we should have shut up night with an old Comedy: the Prince of Millane shall have Mellida, and thou shouldest have

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Nobody, good sweet uncle. I tell you, sir, I have 39. servants, and my monkey that makes the fortieth. Now I love all of them lightly for something, but affect none of them seriously for anything. One is a passionate fool, and he flatters me above belief: the second is a testy ape, and he rails at me beyond reason: the third is as grave as some Censor, and he strokes up his mustachoes three times, and makes six plots of set faces, before he speaks one wise word: the fourth is as dry, as the bur of an artichoke; the fifth paints, and hath always a good colour for what he speaks : the sixth

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Stay, stay, sweet niece, what makes you thus suspect young gallants worth.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: O , when I see one wear a periwig, I dread his hair; another wallow in a great slop, I mistrust the proportion of his thigh; and wears a ruffled boot, I fear the fashion of his leg. Thus, something in each thing, one trick in everything makes me mistrust imperfection in all parts; and there is the full point of my addiction.

body.stage: Enter Galeatzo, Matzagente, and Balurdo in maskery.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: The room is too scant: boys, stand in there, close.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: In faith, fair sir, I am too sad to dance.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: How is that, how is that? too sad? By heaven dance,
And grace him too ;, or, go to, I say no more.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: A burning glass, the word splendent Phoebo?
It is too curious, I conceit it not.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Faith, I will tell thee. I will no longer burn, then you will shine and smile upon my love. For look ye fairest, by your pure sweets,
sp.l: I do not dote upon your excellence.
And faith, unless you shed your brightest beams
Of sunny favour, and acceptive grace
Upon my tender love, I do not burn:
Marry but shine, and I will reflect your beams,
sp.p: with fervent ardour. Faith I would be loath to flatter thee fair soul, because I love, not dote, court like thy husband; which thy father swears, tomorrow morn I must be. This is all, and now from henceforth, trust me Mellida, I will not speak one wise word to thee more.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: I trust ye.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: By my troth, I will speak pure fool to thee now.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: You will speak the liker yourself.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Good faith, I will accept of the coxcomb, so you will not refuse the bauble.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Nay good sweet, keep them both, I am enamoured of neither.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Go to, I must take you down for this. Lend me your ear.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: A glow worm, the word? Splendescit tantum tenebris.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O, Lady, the glow worm figurates my valour: which shineth brightest in most dark, dismal and horrid achievements.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Or rather, your glow worm represents your wit, which only seems to have fire in it, though indeed it is but an ignis fatuus, and shines only in the dark dead night of fools admiration.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Lady, my wit hath spurs, if it were disposed to ride you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Faith sir, your wits spurs have but walking rowels; dull, blunt, they will not draw blood: the gentlemen ushers may admit them the Presence, for any wrong they can do to Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Truly, I have strained a note above Ela, for a deuise; look you, it is a fair ruled singing book: the word, Perfect, if it were pricked.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Though you are masked, I can guess who you are by your wit. You are not the exquisite the most rarely shaped Balurdo.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Who, I? No I am not sir Ieffrey Balurdo. I am not as well known by my wit, as an alehouse by a red lattice. I am not worthy to love and be beloved of Flauia.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I will not scorn to favour such good parts, as are applauded in your rarest self.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Truly, you speak wisely, and like a Gentlewoman of fourteen years of age. You know the stone called Iapis; the nearer it comes to the fire, the hotter it is: and the bird, which the Geometricians call Auis, the farther it is from the earth, the nearer it is to the heaven: and love, the nigher it is to the flame, the more remote (there is a word, remote) the more remote it is from the frost, Your wit is quick, a little thing pleaseth a young Lady, and a small favour contenteth an old Courtier; and so, sweet mistress I truss my codpiece point.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: What might import this flourish? bring us word.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Stand away: here is such a company of fly-boats, hulling about this galleass of greatness, that there is no boarding him.
sp.l: Do you hear yon thing called, Duke?

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: How now blunt Feliche, what is the news?

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.p: Yonder is a knight, hath brought Andrugio's head, and craves admittance to your chair of state.

body.stage: Cornets sound a Cynet: enter Andrugio in armour.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Conduct him with attendance sumptuous,
Sound all the pleasing instruments of joy:
Make triumph, stand on tiptoe whilst we meet:
O sight most gracious, o revenge most sweet!

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: We vow, by the honour of our birth, to recompense any man that bringeth Andrugio's head, with twenty thousand double Pistolets, and the endearing to our choicest love.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: We still with most unmoved resolved confirm
Our large munificence: and hear breath
A sad and solemn protestation:
When I recall this vow, O, let our house
Be even commanded, stained, and trampled on,
As worthless rubbish of nobility.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Then, here, Piero, is Andrugios head,
Royally casked in a helm of steel:
Give me thy love, and take it. My dauntless soul
Hath that unbounded vigour in his spirits,
That it can bear more rank indignity,
With less impatience, than thy cankered hate
Can sting and venom his untainted worth,
With the most viperous sound of malice. Strike;
O, let no glimpse of honour light thy thoughts,
If there be any heat of royal breath
Creeping in thy veins, O stifle it.
Be still thyself, bloody and treacherous.
Fame not thy house with an admired act
Of princely pity. Piero, I am come,
To soil thy house with an eternal blot
Of savage cruelty; strike, or bid me strike.
I pray my death; that thy never dying shame
Might live immortal to posterity.
Come, be a princely hangman, stop my breath.
O dread thou shame, no more than I dread death.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: We are amazed, our royal spirits numbed,
In stiff astonished wonder at thy prowess,
Most mighty, valiant, and high towering heart.
We blush, and turn our hate upon ourselves,
For hating such an unpeered excellence.
I joy my state: him whom I loathed before,
That now I honour, love; nay more, adore.

body.stage: The still Flutes sound a mournfull Cynet. Enter a Cofin.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: But stay: what tragic spectacle appears,
Whose body bear you in that mournful hearse?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The breathless trunk of young Antonio.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Antonio (ay me) my Lord, my love, my

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Sweet precious issue of most honoured blood,
Rich hope, ripe virtue, O untimely loss.
Come hither friend. prithee do not weep:
Why, I am glad he is dead, he shall not see
His fathers vanquished, by his enemy.
Even in princely honour, nay prithee speak.
How died the wretched boy?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My Lord

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I hope he died yet like my son, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Alas, my Lord

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: He died unforced, I trust, and valiantly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Poor gentleman, being

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Did his hand shake, or his eye look dull,
His thoughts reel, fearful when he struck the stroke?
And if they did, I will rend them out the hearse,
Rip up his cerecloth, mangle his bleak face;
That when he comes to heaven, the powers divine
Shall never take notice that he was my son.
I will quite disclaim his birth: nay prithee speak:
And it were not hooped with steel, my breast would break.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: O that my spirit in a sigh could mount,
Into the Sphere, where thy sweet soul doth rest.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: O that my tears, bedewing thy wan cheek,
Could make new spirit sprout in thy cold blood.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Verily, he looks as pitifully, as a poor Iohnas:
I am true knight, I could weep like a stoned horse.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Villain, it is thou hast murdered my son.
Thy unrelenting spirit (thou black dog,
That tookest no passion of his fatal love)
Hath forced him give his life untimely end.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: O that my life, her love, my dearest blood
Would but redeem one minute of his breath.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I seize that breath. Stand not amazed great states:
I rise from death, that never lived till now.
Piero, keep thy vow, and I enjoy
More unexpressed height of happiness,
Than power of thought can reach: if not,lo here
There stands my tomb, and here a pleasing stage:
Most wished spectators of my Tragedy,
To this end have I feigned, that her fair eye,
For whom I lived, might bless me ere I die.

sp.speaker: Mell.
sp.l: Can breath depaint my unconceived thoughts?
Can words describe my infinite delight,
Of seeing thee, my Lord Antonio?
O no conceit, breath, passion, words be dumb,
Whilst I instill the dew of my sweet bliss,
In the soft pressure of a melting kiss;
Sic, sic iuuat ire sub vmbras.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Fair son (now I will be proud to call thee son)
Enjoy me thus; my very breast is thine:
Possess me freely, I am wholly thine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dear father.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Sweet son, sweet son; I can speak no more:
My joys passion flows above the shore,
And chokes the current of my speech.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Young Florence prince, to you my lips must beg,
For a remittance of your interest.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: In your fair daughter, with all my thought,
So help me faith, the naked truth I will unfold;
He that was never hot, will soon be cold,

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: No man else makes claim unto her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: The valiant speak truth in brief: no

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Truly, for sir Ieffrey Balurdo, he disclaims to have had anything in her,

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: Then here I give her to Antonio.
Royal, valiant, most respected prince,
Let us clip our hands; I will thus observe my vow;
I promised twenty thousand double Pistolets,
With the endearing to my dearest love,
To him that brought thy head; thine be the gold,
To solemnise our houses unity:
My love be thine, then all I have be thine.
Fill us fresh wine, the form we will take by this:
We will drink a health, while they two sip a kiss.
Now, there remains no discord that can sound
Harsh accents to the ear of our accord:
So please your niece to match.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Troth uncle, when my sweet faced cuz hath told me how she likes the thing, called wedlock; maybe I will take a survey of the check-roll of my servants; and he that hath the best parts of, I will prick him down for my husband.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: For passion of love now, remember me to my mistress, Lady Rosaline, when she is pricking down the good parts of her servants. As I am true knight, I grow stiff: I shall carry it.

sp.speaker: Pier.
sp.l: I will.
Sound Lidian wires, once make a pleasing note,
On Nectar streams of your sweet airs, to float.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here ends the comic crosses of true love:
O may the passage most successful prove.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Gentlemen, though I remain an armed Epilogue, I stand not as a peremptory challenger of desert, either for him that composed the Comedy, or for us that acted it: but a most submissive suppliant for both. What imperfection you have seen in us, leave with us, and we will amend it; what hath pleased you, take with you, and cherish it. You shall not be more ready to embrace anything commendable, then we will endeavour to amend all things reprovable. What we are, is by your favour. What we shall be, rests all in your applausive encouragements.
sp.l: Exit.
